text: -- shouldn’t be more than a few days at most. You were recommended for the journey because of your familiarity with the territory...
The territory?
Romania, yes.
I’ve never been in that part of the world... Burke stops: Really? SISTER IRENE (CONT’D) There must have been some mistake. I apologize if coming here was a waste of your time...

No. No apology necessary. Cardinal Conroy is a man who doesn’t make mistakes. I’m sure he had his reasons for selecting you. I'll still need your help at the convent since access for anyone but nuns is extremely limited. How long will it take for you to get ready for travel?  11.
Not long at all, Father.

Good. Collect your things. And Sister -- we'll need to wear civilian clothes while traveling. This is one time we don’t need to broadcast our faith... Sister Irene nods. Turns and begins to walk back to the hospital, her head bowed. Father Burke watches her go. As from somewhere, A SCREAM --
It’s Frenchie. Waking up from an awful nightmare. Soaked in sweat. Eyes and bleary, a sign that this night terror isn’t his first He looks around the

Like he’s trying to remember where he is. Trying to convi himself it was just a dream. Or maybe it’s because he’s finally hearing that -- RapRapRap. From somewhere below. Head and heart pounding, he gets off of a small cot and w the sleep away from his face as he stumbles over to the
That RAPPING a little louder now. A little more urgent. H starts down the stairs.

Coming, coming... At the bottom, he reaches a DOOR. Opens it and standing i its threshold is -- -- Father Burke and Sister Irene. Wearing plain, pedestri clothes in an effort to blend in. His eyes drop down to Father Burke’s worn LEATHER SATCHEL. Suspicious...

-.-what is it?  12. He looks beyond them. Out into an EMPTY STREET of -- Brasov, Romania Like a lot of Romania, there is a fairy-tale quality to i architecture and landscape. Except I don’t think our stor ends with ‘...and they all lived happily ever after.’ I’m not even sure it ends with ‘...and they all lived.’ Speaking of which --
Mr. Thierault? Frenchie isn’t so sure he wants to confirm this. He looks over at Sister Irene. Suddenly aware of her. To Burke --
Jealous husband or an angry father?
I’m sorry -- what?
It’s usually one of the two when an older man and young, beautiful and not so innocent girl show up on my doorstep at this hour of the morning...
It’s three in the afternoon. And I beg your pardon, Mr. Thierault, but you and I have never met. Frenchie eyes her up an down.
Then perhaps it’s time we did. He grabs her hand in both of his. Doesn’t let go.
Call me Frenchie. Everyone does... Smiles. Turning on the charm.
We are here, Mr. Thierault, because of the nun you found at the Abbey. Oh. Shit.  A nun?! 13.
How’d you -- (wait...) Are you a priest?
And she’s a nun. Immediately lets go of her hand. Smooth.
Forgive me for my impure thoughts, Sister... But I had no idea. I’ve never seen a nun out of her vestments. Not that I’m opposed to it... She blushes.
Mr. Thierault -- Frenchie -- the Abbey -- is it far from here?
In matter of distance, no. But it takes time to get to. Unfortunately your timing couldn’t be worse. Any day now this village will be overrun with the communist army...
We'll do our best to act quickly. Do you know someone who can take us there?
No. I’ve discovered that everyone in this town pretends like the Abbey doesn’t exist. Even talking about it will get you in trouble.
If I may ask, why were you there?
I was delivering their quarterly supplies... The Abbey apparently has had an arrangement with the town for decades...  14.
So then you can take us. Hold on Frenchie. His eyes. Dark and haunted. You just kn he’d rather do anything else than go back there.
I wish I could help you but maybe there’s somebody better suited. Sister Irene looks at him.
Please. Fuck. Maybe he can say no to a priest but he definitely c say no to a pretty face. Even if she is a nun.

Frenchie leads them to a rusted bucket of a TRUCK. As he circles around, Father Burke puts their SUITCASES into it bed. And then -- The Truck drives off with them. Revealing Frenchie standing by a HORSE-DRAWN WAGON. Both wagon and horses have seen better days.

You took a plane from Rome. A bus from Bucharest. But now you travel by horse. It’s the only way to reach the abbey. It might be 1952 where you’re from but out here they’re still in the Dark Ages... (attendez...) Where are you things? Still confused, Father Burke looks down the street at the Truck slowly rumbling away. G-ddamnit. And right before Sister Irene bursts out laughing -- Frenchie WHISTLES after the Truck. Its brakes brighten.
Recovered, strapped tight to the Tall Board of the  15.

ClopClopClopping along a bumpy barely-a-road that cuts through spiring mountains peeking between pines. Frenchie in the Box Seat. Father Burke and Sister Irene sit in the back. Burke stud another Crossword Puzzle folded over on his knee. Sister Irene studies him.
Beginning. Eight letters. With a W. Shows Sister Irene.
Dawning?
Dawning. Writes it in.
Does it work?
You have a knack for this, Sister.
Beginner’s luck. I never really liked puzzles growing up...
It’s not the puzzles I like as much as I like the answers. I like the certainty of the answers. We don’t get much of that luxury in the lives we've been called for...
But isn’t that where faith is supposed to step in?
Is it? (pause) How long have you been a novitiate?
...about three years.  16. Says that like she knows what’s coming next.
Three years. And you still haven't taken your Temporary Vows?
Temporary vows? I was under the impression there wasn’t anything temporary about being a Nun...
There is a formation process to becoming a Bride of Christ.
Temporary Vows would help prepare me for a life of total consecration...
Would, Sister? Or will? Busted. He looks back at her, curious. Sister Irene a lit flustered. She gathers herself.
What brings a Frenchman to the countryside of Romania?
Actually I’m French Canadian but don’t tell anyone. It doesn’t sound as romantic... He winks. She rolls her eyes.

And I’m here because I wanted to see the world. But when I arrived in Brasov and met the people I knew this was where I was meant to be -- I wanted to help them in any way I can... An unexpected side of him.

That’s very noble of you. Sister Irene and Frenchie exchange a meaningful look when Wagon JOLTS to a sudden stop.  17. Startles ‘em. SISTER IRENE (CONT’D) What happened? Surrounded by the Pines. Casting dark shadows. Frenchie h off the Wagon. He grabs his SHOTGUN.
Is everything okay?
We walk the rest of the way. The horses won’t go any further. As Father Burke and Sister Irene step off --
Perhaps you should get new horses.

It’s not the horses, Father. It’s what lies ahead. They’re scared. The Abbey -- the locals say it is a cursed place. The horses agree. Sister Irene stares into the darkness between the pines. Everything so still. So silent. A sense someone is watchi Burke circles around and begins to unstrap the suitcases. Frenchie grabs his arm: Please...
Why don’t you keep your things here and you two stay in town tonight? I'd feel better about it. As Father Burke continues with the suitcases --

“Fear not, for I am with you; be not dismayed, for I am your God; I will strengthen you, I will help you, I will uphold you with my righteous right hand.” Frenchie looks over at Sister Irene. Back to Burke.
J’ai essaye. I tried. They walk.  18.
Branches block the sun. The darkness seems to dampen the sounds. Maybe that’s why everything seems so... dead.
If I may ask, Father, why is it the Church sends you on such tasks?
The Church reaches out to me when it needs an investigation into unusual phenomenon associated with Catholicism. Unofficially they call it ‘miracle hunting’...
I thought we were here because of a suicide...

We are. But I confess that is only part of our investigation. We also have orders from the Vatican to determine if the grounds are still... Holy. And off her look -- Frenchie stops. Points through the trees:
I can give you my opinion on the matter now, Father. They look and see -- A CASTLE. Or it used to be, anyway. A long time ago. But the last several hundred years it’s been home to

Look, there are no vampires in this movie. But if there w you'd totally understand why just by looking at this plac It’s a FORTRESS. Round Towers. Walls of Stone. Built to withstand the attack of Foreign Invaders and Time Itself.
That doesn’t look like any Abbey I’ve seen, Father...  19. Father Burke throws her a look: No, me neither.

SLOWLY PULL BACK, revealing -- Whoa. It is not alone. Just one of HUNDREDS. Big Crosses. Littl Crosses. Iron Crosses. Stone Crosses. Stick. Twig. Woven. mean, the Hill of Crosses ain’t got nothing on this place It’s like a MOAT OF RELIGION that surrounds the Abbey. Father Burke, Sister Petra and Frenchie approach. Their e on the Abbey that looms ahead of them. Father Burke notes TOWER that appears to have suffered some damage.
A result of the war?

Bombing raids, yes. I’ve heard stories of how the ground shook for days after them. I have tried to find more information on the castle itself but there is no record of it in the village and the locals only spit when it is mentioned...
Spit?
To ward off evil.
It’s an old and silly superstition... Drawing closer --
Did you try to contact someone inside when you found the nun?
I did. But no one responded. But then again in the two years I've been delivering supplies she was the first nun I’d seen.  20.

It is a convent of cloistered nuns. They live with a spirit of detachment from material things and being set apart from the world in order to maintain their intimate relationship with Jesus Christ... It isn’t unusual for them to not make contact with an outsider. Good to know.
Did you mention your discovery to anyone in town?
The delivery man I replaced. But he told me to shut up about it...
What does he say about this place?

I’ve only heard him speak of it once -- when he was pissed -- er, sorry -- inebriated. But it was gibberish... (remembering...) Mostly. Drawing closer to the entrance, Burke stops. Looks down. BLOOD on the stone. It’s like a Rorschach Test. If you as it kinda looks like... ..-nah, nevermind.
That’s where I found her. They look up. See the Frayed End of the Rope swing in the breeze. But look -- beyond it -- in the
A Figure. Watches them. Before it steps away. Father Burke makes the Sign of the Cross. Kneels down. Touches the blood. Still wet. Fresh.
How is that possible? It’s been weeks....  21.
I told you. This place. What’s the opposite of a miracle, Father? Burke looks at him. Question cuts deep for some reason. B he doesn’t answer. He moves over to the

Big. Heavy. Built to stay closed. Burke pulls on a Rusted Iron Ring anyway. Hinges groaaaaaaaan as the Door opens. Burke pauses. Like he’s steeling himself. Another Sign of the Cross and then he enters, disappearin into the shadows beyond. Sister Irene soon follows. Frenchie about to enter as well but he stops. Remembers something. Might as well... He spits. And then steps inside a

Used to funnel outside invaders so they can be easily attacked. Speaking of invaders -- We catch up to Father Burke and Sister Irene. Right outsi of a Small Door. Burke opens it and they all enter the

Probably used to be the Lord’s Hall when this was a castl Lit by CANDLES for any natural light is sparse in here. As it is with the rest of the castle. Fucking great. The furnishings are few. Mainly those shelves of DUSTY BO A LARGE CONFESSIONAL BOOTH inspired by Rodin’s ‘Gates of Hell’. And that LONE HIGH BACK CHAIR. It’s not a throne. But close enough. Behind it, the only PASSAGEWAY leading further into the convent is blocked off by a PORTCULLIS -- a vertical clos gate consisting of a latticed grille made of metal. Along the Exterior Wall, SEVERAL PLASTER MALE AND FEMALE FACES hang in intervals on rectangular slabs of White Sto  22. Unnerved by their blank white eyes, Frenchie approaches o Gets close. Because he thinks he hears someone behind it faintly whisper-sing a familiar tune: A la claire fontaine m’en allant promener, J’ai trouvé l’ si belle que je m’y suis --
They must be the Death Masks of the people inside those tombs. Frenchie steps away. Sister Irene and Father Burke behind him. He’s rattled. Did he really just hear that singing? And wait --
-- tombs?
Here. In the walls. But before I get to those...

text: ...-who the hell is that now seated in the High Back Chai mean I know it’s a Nun. She’s wearing a PARLOR VEIL. Long black, it covers her face and falls onto her chest. That must be THE ABBESS. And she does not move as she presumably watches -- Sister Irene, Father Burke, and Frenchie look over the To ETCHINGS -- names, dates -- faded. Hard to read.
Senses the Figure behind them. She turns. Suspicions confirmed. She moves toward it.

Hello? Father Burke and Frenchie turn. Sees the Abbess. Frenchie looks over at the others, like -- Is that normal? SISTER IRENE (CONT’D) Please excuse our unannounced arrival...  23. No answer. No movement. SISTER IRENE (CONT’D) Hello? Nothing. Unnerved, Sister Irene stops. Looks back at the others: Now what? She turns back to the Abbess. And now sees the Abbess has cocked her head right at her. Staring at her through the veil. God help us.
What is it you want?
I am Father Michael Burke. This is Sister Irene Petra. To whom do we have the pleasure of speaking to?
I am the Reverend Mother. You are a priest? What is a priest without his collar?
Forgive our appearance. But as you know, Reverend Mother, clothes don’t make the Catholic. We are here on behalf of Rome to inquire about the recent death in your convent...
What recent death?
There was a nun. I found her outside. By the entrance.
(in French) Is that so? Frenchie. Uneasy. Doesn’t want to respond. To Frenchie --
Would you allow us a moment please? Frenchie nods. Throws a look to Sister Irene. Back at Bur and the Abbess. And then leaves. Okay, round two:  Jab. Block. Jab. Uppercut. 24.
You should leave with him.
Are you saying you weren't aware of the recent passing of the Nun?
What is it you want, Father?
Rome is concerned about the safety and well-being of your cloister. I'd like to speak with the Sisters so I can offer my assurances to the Church...
I can offer the assurance you seek.
I'm afraid that won’t suffice. They’11l just send more and perhaps less diplomatic Church Officials.

Yes, Father. (pause) However now we are about to take our Vespers followed by the Great Silence which continues until after breakfast... Come back tomorrow and you will find the answers you seek... There is lodging in the Chapel. You may stay there. End of Round.

The Gray Stone of the Abbey Walls. The White Knuckles of Frenchie’s grip on his shotgun. Suspect of everything.  25. Like a castle guard, he patrols the entrance. Can’t shake feeling of being watched. Looks up at the Dark Windows. Is someone up there? Watching him? Grooco000000000000aaaan. He spins. Shotgun at the ready. Sister Irene and Father Burke exit the Abbey. Startled, Frenchie quickly lowers his aim.
Sorry -- I thought -- or rather I wasn’t thinking...
It’s fine, Frenchie.
Who was that in there?
That was the Abbess. She is the second in command of the Abbey.
Why wouldn’t she let us see her?
She was wearing a parlor veil. They are worn when meeting people outside their cloister to maintain the spirit of detachment...
We need to wait until morning to speak with the nuns...
So it’s settled then. You’ll come back with me and stay in town. Burke walks over to the blood again.

That isn’t necessary. There are accommodations for us in the chapel... Frenchie about to protest. But bites his tongue instead.  26. FATHER BURKE (CONT’D) When you found the body, Frenchie, what did you do? Leave it?
No. When no one inside the Abbey responded I moved it to protect her body from the elements. I intended on returning to bury her but I couldn't bring myself to come back here. Not... not alone.
Where did you move it to?
Frenchie leads Father Burke and Sister Irene around the perimeter. Stops outside Storm Cellar-like DOORS.

This is the ice house where I would leave my deliveries. I never saw anyone but they were always gone when I returned... until now. When I found the Sister I thought moving her in here would help... preserve her... He OPENS one of the doors. Motions: After you... Father Burke and Sister Irene stoop down and enter into t

The headache gray daylight spills into it. Their breath m out in front of them as they eye Sister Victoria. Seated upright in the corner. Father Burke about to go over to her but Frenchie reaches and grabs his arm once again: Not so fast.
I should tell you one more thing, Father...
What? Pointing to Sister Victoria --  27.
That isn’t how I left her. Waitwaitwait... They both look over at Frenchie.
What do you mean?
She was laying down when I left her here. Not like that. Sitting up. Um...
He creeps over toward the Sister Victoria’s Body. Needs t get a closer look. On the shelves, food frozen with rot.
While unusual, there have been cases of bodies twitching or sitting up not long after death.
But Father, who knows how long she was dead when I found her.... Father Burke stops. Turns to Frenchie.
You're not helping.

Sorry... Father Burke turns back to Sister Victoria. Kneels beside her. Winces as he sees her head wounds. Makes the Sign of the Cross. His eyes drop down to THAT CROSS she’s clutching in her d frozen hands. But looking closer he sees, wait -- It isn’t just a cross.
What is it, Father? It’s actually --  28.

Looks to be a key of some kind. He tugs at the KEY. But the Rosary it’s attached to is lo in Sister Victoria’s dead fingers. Pulls harder. Rosary SNAPS. Beads scatter. But the Key is free. He inspects it further. Sees an ENGRAVING in its bronze:
Don’t ask me what it means. No idea. Neither does Father Burke. He pockets it as his eyes drift over to the

Leading into the castle. Cracked open. An inch. Maybe two Was someone just watching him through it? A chill. Either from that or the cold. Father Burke turns and faces the others. FATHER BURKE (CONT’D) We should give her a proper burial.

Overgrown with Tombstones and Tall Grass. Next to a SMALL CHAPEL that looks as if it’s still standing by faith alon Father Burke and Sister Irene stand at Sister Victoria’s Fresh Grave. Frenchie stands nearby with a shovel. Heads bowed because --
-- by Whose mercy the faithful departed rest, send Your holy angel to watch over this grave, through Christ our Lord. Amen.

Amen. A BREEZE blows. We hear --  29. Ting... Ting... Ting... Of TINY BELLS staked next to several graves. Sister Irene kneels by one of the Bells. Sees TWINE tied it while the other end of thread disappears into the dirt She tugs on the twine. Ting. Bell rings. Frenchie and Father Burke appear behind her.

It was common practice during the plague when people feared of being buried alive. If you were unfortunate enough for it to happen, you could ring the bell to let those above ground know they’ve made a mistake... Sister Irene stands. They continue on toward a CHAPEL tha looks as if it’s still standing by faith alone.
Aging clouds of dust swirl in the day’s dying light as Fa Burke, Sister Irene and Frenchie enter into the

The Main Part of the Chapel. Sure, it’s a House of God. B probably not one he comes to very often. Rows of creaky p Cracked Stained Glass Windows. An overturned confessional And a LARGE WOODEN CROSS above the Altar. Frenchie sets down a SMALL BOX of supplies. But he’s stil eager to get them both to leave:
Why could you not talk to the sisters now? Why must it wait til morning?
The sisters take a vow of silence from sunset to sunrise. That must be respected...  30.
You should begin heading back yourself. I imagine you don’t want to be caught on those roads when night falls... Frenchie looks up at the HEADLESS STATUE OF THE VIRGIN MA
Better the roads than here, Father.
We'll be fine, Frenchie. Come back tomorrow. That should give us enough time to get what we need.
Yes, Father. He turns and begins to exit the Church. Throws one last look back at Father Burke and Sister Iren His grim expression says he isn’t so sure they’1ll be fin He’s right.

Sister Irene opens a CLOSET. Digs out old BLANKETS and BE SHEETS. Sniffs them. Surprised they aren’t mildewed. She begins to head down to a Guest Room when she pauses t look at SEVERAL FRAMED PHOTOGRAPHS hanging on the walls. Pictures of the Convent and the Nuns. Years gone by. In t most recent one we see a familiar face -- Sister Charlott Whom we met in the second Annabelle. Sister Irene continues on to the
But the light is scarce. She sees an OIL LANTERN on a nearby shelf. A BOX of MATCH next to it. She strikes the match and we --
Glows between Father Burke and Sister Irene as they sit a small table ina  31.
Eating BEAN PASTE with smoked meat. A staple of tradition Romanian cuisine. It looks... edible. The Table Wine help Father Burke has his Crossword Puzzle open next to his pl
Transferals.
Transferals?
Transferals. Thinks...
..-passing? Father Burke writes it in. Stops. Erases.
Not enough letters.
I told you it was beginner’s luck.
Perhaps. He continues to go over his puzzle. Sister Irene has something to say. You can tell by the wa she sneaks looks at Father Burke. Say it now? Or... now? What about... Now:

Father. You mentioned miracle hunting before. Is that -- is that a role you sought out? Father Burke doesn’t look up from his food. Because he doesn’t really want to have this conversation right now. Or ever.  32.

I was a chaplain in the war, stationed in near Eus in the south of France. There was... an incident. A child with visions. My work with the boy drew the attention of the Church and because of that I was recruited to look into the more unusual matters involving the Church...
So you know Bishop Form? That gets him to look up.
How do you --

Because he helped me when I was younger... Father Burke sets his fork down: Really... SISTER IRENE (CONT’D) I had a series of visions when I was a girl. My father believed one of two things: I was mentally unstable or worse, I was a liar. But word of my visions reached the church -- Cardinal Conroy specifically -- and he sent Bishop Form to meet with me. Days before I was to be committed, they contacted my Father and convinced him of a third option...
That they were a miracle.
That they could be.
And Bishop Form, he spoke to you about these visions?
He did.
And did he consider possession?  33.
Yes. But after his investigation he determined I was of pure spirit and suggested I dedicate myself to the Lord...
Have you had any visions since?
No. Burke nods. His thoughts distant. SISTER IRENE (CONT’D) What about the boy? Did his eventually stop as well? Father Burke flinches. A painful memory.
Yes. He stands. Takes his plate over to the sink. Exits out of Kitchen. Leaving Sister Irene all alone. With only more questions.
The Nave. The Kitchen. The Altar. The Side Aisle. The Bac Hallway. All are empty. And as silent as the grave. This includes the

In which Father Burke sleeps. We slowly PUSH IN on him. L we're creeping up, ready to pounce. Somewhere behind us - PitterPatterPitterPatterPitterPatter.... Of FOOTSTEPS. And a playful GIGGLE. Loud enough that Father Burke sits up. He squints into th gloom of night. Something there? Or maybe he was just dre PitterPatterPitter... No.  34. That wasn’t any dream. He throws back the covers and gets out of his cot. Moves into the
Looks in on Sister Irene in the Second Guest Bedroom. Asl in her cot. Undisturbed by... More FOOTSTEPS. Father Burke spins and follows them into the

Still empty. Still quiet. Father Burke peers into the sha that hang like cobwebs. Creak. Behind him. He turns and sees A BOY. Standing still near the Side Entrance. Silhouetted in the darkness. Father Burke. A flicker of recognition on his face. Is that...? He takes a step forward for a better look but -- Boy takes off. Outside the entrance. Father Burke hurries after him.

A starless, moonless night. Feels like it’s near lifeless too. As Father Burke pauses by a crumbling tombstone. Where’d the boy go? Father Burke walks deeper into the cemetery. His eyes dar from grave to grave. Searching. The Boy could be anywhere Or maybe he’s gone entirely. Because he doesn’t seem to b anywhere. Damnit. Father Burke begins to turn back but -- The Boy.  35. There he is. Standing still in the darkness. His head hun And whoa, it looks like he’s SPROUTED WINGS from his back Who is this? Unnerved, Father Burke slowly approaches. Slow and deliberate. Doesn’t want to scare the boy away. As he draws closer, he realizes those wings. They’re ston Because the boy is standing in front of an ANGEL STATUE. Boy keeps his head down. His eyes off Burke. Father Burke uses this as an opportunity to get even closer when -- The Boy SNAPS HIS EYES up at Burke. Burke stops. Can’t believe it --

Daniel? The Boy begins to convulse, like he’s choking. Something caught in is throat. Something big. He HACKS. Opens his mouth. And slowly VOMITS out a LARGE SNAKE. The Snake hissssssssssses as it writhes out of The Boy’s stretched open mouth. Slithers into the grass. Startled, Father Burke backs away and start to hurry acro the cemetery. Looks back over his shoulder and -- Falls into a hole in the ground. A SHALLOW GRAVE. Burke l hard in an Open Coffin. Lid SLAMS shut and

Burke SLAMS his fists against the lid. Struggling to get open. But it won’t budge. And what’s worse is... Thud. Thud. Thud. Right on the other side of the lid. The sound unmistakabl It’s Clumps of Dirt. He’s being buried alive. Father Burke SCREAMS and we --
Sister Irene shoots straight up out of bed. Like she just a terrible dream. Gasping for air. She looks around the

All seems normal. But still. A feeling creeps over her. A sense that something ain’t right. And then -- A SHADOW passes over. Walking by. Startles her. She gets out of bed. As behind her the moonlight casts SHADOWS on the wall. Branches. Bed posts. Sister Irene lights the Oil Lantern. As it brightens, tho shadows on the wall fade. Except for one. A very familiar silhouette. But Sister Irene doesn’t see it as she carries the oil lantern out into
Sees the door to Father Burke’s Room is ajar. She approac trying to get a glimpse inside. See if he’s okay.

Father? No answer. Hesitant, she creeeaks open the door further to find it’s empty. Concerned, Sister Irene turns and is faced with -- THAT SHADOW on the wall behind her. In the Unholy Shape o The Nun. It moves. Walking along the wall and floor. Toward the Nave. Where she hears DISTANT CHANTING. WHISPERING. And PRAYING. Unsettled, Sister Irene follows the shadow into the

And sees Dark Figures. Sitting in the pews. Facing the Al like they’re listening to a sermon. Their backs toward us They're NUNS. SISTER IRENE (CONT’D) Excuse me?  37. Waits. But no reaction. She starts toward one of the Nuns closest to her but stops when she sees -- The Shadow of The Nun. It has returned. And begins to walk along the Chapel walls. Sister Irene watches. Eyes following the shadow. It turns around as it moves into a MIRROR.

The shadow becomes a BODY. You can’t see her face but you don’t need to. You know. It’s The Demon Nun. Standing in front of the Altar. Under that Huge Wooden Cross. The Demon Nun raises her hand and points at Irene. SCREECHES. And now all the Other Nuns turn and look at Sister Irene well. Their faces gruesome and pale. Sister Irene snaps back to look at them behind her. But no one is there. And as she processes whether she imagines this --
The Huge Wooden Cross CRASHES to the ground. Terrified, Sister Irene turns and runs out of the Nave. Returning into the

Calling out for -- SISTER IRENE (CONT’D) Father! Checks the Kitchen. Priest’s Study. The Meeting Room. But Father Burke is nowhere to be found. Her panic increasing Sister Irene stumbles out of the Chapel.  38. EXT. CHAPEL - NIGHT -— CONTINUOUS Sister Irene stops right outside the exit. Suddenly confronted with the night. Her eyes scan the landscape. She feels too exposed. But then -- Tingtingting... Sister Irene looks over in the direction of the cemetery. TingTingTingTing... She moves over into the

Tombstones in shadow seem like abandoned ancient alien artifacts. Sister Irene walks among them. A stranger in a even stranger land as she continues to follow the -- TingTingTinTingTingTingTing... Leads her to an OLD GRAVE. She kneels down. Sets the Lant beside her. It illuminates the TINY BELL continuing to ri She stops the bell. Pauses. Like, now what? But then she looks down at the ground. Scared, she puts her ear close to the earth. Listens. And through the dirt she hears -- THE MUFFLED SCREAMS OF FATHER BURKE. Sister Irene. Stunned. How is that possible? This grave looks like it’s been filled for decades. Nevermind that for now --

Father! FATHER! Starts to dig her fingers into the dirt. Scraping it away desperate. Continue to call out for -- SISTER IRENE (CONT’D) Father! I can hear you!  39. She looks around for something to help her. Sees the SHOV Frenchie used earlier leaning against the grave. Gets up. Grabs it. She begins to dig. And dig. And dig. Thump! Must be the coffin. Not six feet under. But far enough. L the shovel drop. Returns to using her hands. As she sweeps away the surface dirt, she reveals HUNDREDS TINY CROSSES. Scratched deep into the lid of the COFFIN. Father Burke continues to POUND against the lid. Sister Irene pries it open. Father Burke sits right up, gasping for life. He grasps onto Sister Irene like she’s just pulled him fr the depths of death. Eventually able to muster --
Thank you... Sister... thank... Streaked with dirt and sweat, Sister Irene looks past Fat Burke and back into the coffin. It’s filled with BOOKS.
